comments.commentBody:
Gov. Walker, the primary concern is not about Republican policies. The Founders envisioned a country where different perspectives worked together and provided each other with checks and balances to keep us all grounded. With a single party controlling all branches of government an American democracy cannot exist.

Being certain of any path, truth if you will, is simply arrogance.
He remains delusional. Those one hundred thousand protestors he refuses to call citizens, instead labeling the "liberal" makes him a continuing disgrace.

What we have to do is keep on demonstrating against our incompetent, lying, right wing government. If the supreme court, follows the legislative and executive branches, as it probably will, the only hope is the streets. Why is Walker, the anti worker, anti health care, anti environmental, billionaire loving, follow the "leader"
politician on the editorial page anyway? I guess the idea is to be balanced. Too bad. His space should be in breitbart, not the NY times.

States rights. Ok John C. Calhoun. We get it. The south, bitter about reconstruction has risen again and is exacting it's revenge on the uppity freed slaves and Yankees.

There were two huge mistakes made by Lincoln.
1) He didn't allow the confederate states to secede, which if they had, would've resulted in their inevitable financial ruin.
2) Given that he chose to fight the confederate traitors, He didn't supply Sherman with enough matches

The idea that Wisconsin is a success because of Scott Walker's policies is laughable. It's true that it's not the debacle of Kansas, but the good times in Wisconsin might be seen as part of the overall economic recovery rather than evidence that those Republican polices work.
It sounds great for states to decide because they are "closer" to the people than the federal government. It sounds great until you realize that the more intimate environment makes corruption and buying the polices that wealthy individuals and corporations, who are of course people, want much easier.
Despite the scandals that plague the federal government, there is far more evidence of malfeasance at local and state levels.
So what you're saying is that New Yorkers can't govern themselves because corruption is endemic in your society? Pretty pathetic.

All of these "small government" Republicans, once they control the state government, they immediately move to pre-empt any city ordinances they don't like. Higher minimum wages where the cost of living is higher? Fuggedaboutit.

Under Scott Walker, Wisconsin, once an example to the whole nation, has become a shadow of its former self. Employment is lagging. The roads and bridges are a mess. Our finances are headed for billions of dollars in debt. Projects have been delayed, as much as doubling their original cost. Five hundred million dollars ($500,000,000) has been stripped from the university system, wrecking a once proud institution. Walker has stripped the worker of the right to bargain for better wages and working conditions. He has driven out talented and experienced people from a state administration that was once a model of efficiency. The state is now being run by the wealthy few, and those who protest are intimidated, prosecuted and threatened with far worse than Walker even claims.
Contrary to his every word, Walker's approach is a stellar example of how to ignore the people and serve only special interests.

Shame on Walker and other Republicans who want to double our poverty rate from 15 to 30%.  For the now elderly baby boomers he will have us go from 9% to 45% living in poverty.   How cruel and ignorant, to want to go back to the days before the war on poverty, jobs programs, educational assistance, food stamps, Medicaid and other government assistance programs which have so far provided America a huge return on investment and improved Americans quality of living.  The cost of enormous increases in poverty will undoubtedly cost much much more.  Walker's position is immoral.  It is totally without reason to think that our incredibly rich country cannot give aid to people who have or will spend their bodies and lives working for family, community and America.  But when shareholders are global citizens; though, corporations' unfettered stranglehold on despots like Walker will determine our fate…Thank you, Justice Roberts.  I do not want to become like China, a third world country with 1st world technology.
Oh, that explains it. Thanks. Some of us had the idea that he might be a liar and perjurer.

The Republicans have a limited window to get cracking on an investigation of this outsider, before they get tarred with his brush. Either Putin has something on a bunch of them too, or they hope to pull off a bunch of bad legislation quickly, get Trump's signature on it, and then start the investigation.

A) Fire the sucker.
B) Sic a special prosecutor on him, so he can spend the next four years being tortured with depositions and subpoenas
C) Both.

Thank you Gail.
Seems like these stories are showing how Trump's team  has been openly lying in front of Congress, but maybe I haven't read enough of Trump's tweets to get fully indoctrinated.
"Only in Cleveland?"  Gail, I prefer "only in Vegas."  Because what happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas."
He should resign as should all the Uber Republicans of the trump administration who think they have their own set of rules.

So you're okay with Russia trashing Ukraine's autonomy and desire to join the EU, annex Crimea, commit war crimes in Syria, invade Afghanistan, and meddle in Lybia and Iraq? How much is that for letting people determine their own futures? Why was Obama blamed for NOT interfering more in Syria then?

He knows. I doubt that his own son in law met the Russian ambassador at Trump tower and he forget to mention it to dear old dad. He also didn't enter through the front door for some odd reason- can't imagine why....
Trump is in debt to Russians. The Russian oil oligarchs are calling the shots- and they are in close ties with Putin- one and the same.
Follow the money. It's time to subpoena Trump's tax returns. It's time to correct the hugest blunder in American history- electing the ultimate Manchurian Candidate.

Utter nonsense. What a majority of citizens are “aware” of is the “beast" that has already awoken is pretending to be president. The hate and vitriol was a central theme of his campaign and what “middle ground” has ever been embraced when Obama was President? If this ”culture conflict” is to be avoided the party of denial will need to embrace the truth.

Newsflash: you don't have to be a "secret Russian agent" for your credibility as AG to be called into question. Lying to Congress will do it. But keep on blowing smoke about the media's "credibility." The sleazebags are going to be held accountable.

the president of the United States said, “I think he probably did.”

Why is he (and tons of other politicians) allowed to hedge to the point of meaninglessness? That answer has I, he, did as certainties. Well, we know that Pres. Trump was the person asked the question and that it was about "he", AG Sessions, and no doubt AG Sessions did something, like he ate breakfast, went to the toilet, took the Senate subway, bought some new socks. What is this "think" and "probably" baloney? This president is certainly capable of not hedging, though he cannot possibly be sure that "we are going to make America great again", nor that the ACA will be repealed and replaced at the same time, among myriad other un-hedged assertions he has made without presenting details of how it's going to happen. He is asked a simple yes/no question and is allowed to get away with "think" and "probably". Were I the reporter, I would have answered, "So you don't know. You are guessing." There would have been more hedging, to which the response by the reporter should have been, "We can therefore assume you are not sure if he told the truth or not. Thank you." And walked away without awaiting any further comment to file the story, such as it was.

Poor Jeff, everyone's picking on him because he's not as spectacular a liar as his boss. If lying is an art form Jeffie's lies are crayon stick figures compared to the golden gilt lies of Trump. Where Jeff grew up you just tell a lie and nobody questions it, they're too afraid. Works well in the South, not so good in a Presidential administration.
I'm for a special prosecutor and endless investigations, all up and down the line of the Cabinet. It'll keep them busy and less harmful.

I have mulled over the President's equivocation, "I think...probably...," and I have come to the conclusion that the President is a genius. His strategy vis-à-vis communicating with the American people has been to churn out hail storms--no, cyclones--of insults, lies, rumors, exaggerations, improprieties, artless mistakes and, yes, equivocations--and now, thanks to relativity, he can say anything he pleases with impunity. Gen-ius!

“There's a fine line between genius and insanity...”
-Oscar Levant

"Asked whether he thought Sessions had spoken 'truthfully' on the subject of his Russian conversations, the president of the United States said, 'I think he probably did.'"

So can we assume that Trump will be instructing the FBI to adjust their procedures for conducting security screenings? "Oh, this guy's probably OK, give him a top secret clearance." Well, it would be consistent with how he apparently formulates policy: "Yeah, that sounds good, let's go with that. Now I gotta go tweet about the failing NYT."
It sounds exactly how he probably handled the briefing about the raid in Yemen. "Yeah, that sounds good. Can someone get me some more meat loaf?"
We used to call statements like that  "weasel words".  Still applies.
Sounds like many key delegates in Cleveland were spending late night hours lifting a glass of vodka to GOP (Good Old Putin).

Sen. Kennedy: “Mr. Sessions is a throwback to a shameful era which I know both black and white Americans thought was in our past. It is inconceivable to me that a person of this attitude is qualified to be a U.s. attorney, let alone a U.S. Federal judge. He is, I believe, a disgrace to the Justice Department and he should withdraw his nomination and resign his position.”

It might be credible for Sessions to have gotten confused about why he met the Russian ambassador and what they might have discussed if it were not for the argument about the hacking. It sounds as if he had been trying to address the issue rather than answer the question that was asked. He could have said that, yes, he met with the ambassador, but that the campaign never came up. Would the ambassador have played along if that was a lie?
